quiz.title: Unit 2: Production Possibilities Frontier (Quiz 10)
quiz.subtitle: 2.10 Supply and Demand Basics: Fundamental Market Forces (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Supply, Demand, Market Equilibrium, Price Mechanism

questions.question: The law of demand states that, all else equal:
options: As price increases, quantity demanded increases
As price increases, quantity demanded decreases
Price and quantity demanded are unrelated
Demand is always constant regardless of price
questions.explanation: The law of demand states there is an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded - when price rises, quantity demanded falls, and vice versa.

questions.question: A demand curve slopes downward because:
options: Producers are willing to sell more at higher prices
Consumers buy less when prices are lower
Higher prices reduce consumers' purchasing power and willingness to buy
questions.explanation: The downward slope reflects both the substitution effect (consumers switch to alternatives as price rises) and income effect (higher prices reduce real income).

questions.question: The law of supply states that, all else equal:
options: As price increases, quantity supplied decreases
As price increases, quantity supplied increases
Price and quantity supplied are unrelated
Supply is always constant regardless of price
questions.explanation: The law of supply states there is a direct relationship between price and quantity supplied - when price rises, producers are willing to supply more, and vice versa.

questions.question: Market equilibrium occurs when:
options: Price is at its maximum possible level
There is either a shortage or surplus
questions.explanation: Equilibrium is the price-quantity combination where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied, with no inherent tendency for price to change.

questions.question: A shortage in a market occurs when:
options: Supply and demand are both decreasing
questions.explanation: A shortage (excess demand) happens when quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied at the current price, typically when price is below equilibrium.

questions.question: If there is a surplus in a market, we would expect:
questions.explanation: A surplus (excess supply) creates downward pressure on prices as sellers compete to sell their excess inventory.

questions.question: A change in which factor would shift the entire demand curve?
options: The price of the good itself
questions.explanation: Changes in price cause movement along the demand curve. The entire curve shifts due to changes in income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, or number of buyers.

questions.question: If coffee and tea are substitutes, an increase in the price of coffee will:
questions.explanation: When the price of a substitute rises, consumers switch to the alternative, increasing demand for the substitute good (tea).

questions.question: If smartphones and data plans are complements, an increase in the price of data plans will:
questions.explanation: When the price of a complement rises, demand for both related goods decreases since they are consumed together.

questions.question: A change in which factor would shift the entire supply curve?
options: The price of the good itself
questions.explanation: Changes in price cause movement along the supply curve. The entire curve shifts due to changes in technology, input prices, taxes, expectations, or number of sellers.

questions.question: Improved technology in automobile manufacturing would likely:
questions.explanation: Better technology reduces production costs, making producers willing to supply more cars at each price - this shifts the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: If consumers expect prices to rise significantly in the future, current demand will:
questions.explanation: Expectations of future price increases encourage consumers to buy now rather than later, increasing current demand.

questions.question: The price system serves as a rationing mechanism because:
options: It guarantees equal distribution to all
It allocates goods to those willing and able to pay
questions.explanation: Prices ration scarce goods by allocating them to buyers who value them most (as shown by their willingness to pay) and can afford them.

questions.question: If both demand and supply increase simultaneously, we can expect:
questions.explanation: When both curves shift right, quantity definitely increases, but the effect on price is ambiguous - it depends on the relative magnitude of the shifts.

questions.question: A price ceiling set below the equilibrium price will create:
questions.explanation: A binding price ceiling set below equilibrium prevents price from rising to clear the market, resulting in a persistent shortage (excess demand).

questions.question: A price floor set above the equilibrium price will create:
questions.explanation: A binding price floor set above equilibrium prevents price from falling to clear the market, resulting in a persistent surplus (excess supply).

questions.question: Elasticity of demand measures:
options: How much demand shifts when price changes
How responsive quantity demanded is to price changes
How fast prices change over time
The slope of the demand curve
questions.explanation: Price elasticity of demand measures the percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price - it shows how sensitive consumers are to price changes.

questions.question: If demand is price elastic, an increase in price will cause:
questions.explanation: When demand is elastic, the percentage decrease in quantity demanded exceeds the percentage increase in price, so total revenue decreases.

questions.question: The concept of consumer surplus represents:
options: The profit producers make from selling goods
The difference between what consumers pay and what they're willing to pay
The cost of producing consumer goods
questions.explanation: Consumer surplus is the difference between the maximum price consumers are willing to pay and the actual price they pay, representing the net benefit consumers receive.

questions.question: The fundamental role of prices in a market economy is to:
options: Coordinate economic activity and allocate resources
Keep profits as high as possible
questions.explanation: Prices serve as signals that convey information about scarcity and value, coordinate the actions of buyers and sellers, and ration scarce resources to their most valued uses.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the fundamental concepts of supply and demand and understand how markets coordinate economic activity.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but review the differences between shifts in curves versus movements along curves, and how markets reach equilibrium.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Demand shows what consumers will buy; Supply shows what producers will sell; Equilibrium where they meet; Prices coordinate the market.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember: Demand slopes down (price up, quantity down); Supply slopes up (price up, quantity up); Market clears where supply and demand cross.
